questions.question: I …………………… anything for hours.
questions.description: The present perfect is more common with the time expressions for and since.

questions.question: I believe that professionals ……………………. doctors and teachers are more useful than actors or singers.
questions.description: Either like or such as can be used to give examples.

questions.question: The child …………………… sits in that corner is my nephew.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people.

questions.question: You …………………… behave.
questions.description: All of these expressions indicate ideas such as obligation and necessity.

questions.question: You ......................... quit the job.
questions.description: Must is a modal auxiliary. Questions and negatives are made without do.

questions.question: I haven’t got ……………………… friends.
questions.description: Not any means the same as no.

questions.question: I called him in the morning but he didn’t ……………………. the phone.
questions.description: Use the bare infinitive (v1) after do, does and did.

questions.question: I don’t ……………………… agree with this view.
The situation is getting ……………………day by day.
questions.description: Worse is the comparative form of bad.

questions.question: I am now here ……………………. my mom.
questions.description: Because of is a preposition. It is used before a noun.

questions.question: Work …………………… the best of your ability.
I went home …………………….. I was bored.
questions.description: Because is a conjunction. It is used to connect two clauses.

questions.question: He would have drowned if the rescuers ………………………….. in time.
questions.description: In the third conditional we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: Would you mind my ………………………. the window?
Take anything you …………………………
I knew that she ……………………… support me.
questions.description: Would is the past tense of will.

questions.question: ……………………. I ran, I could not catch up with him.
questions.description: Fronted adjectives/adverbs are possible in a structure with as or though.

questions.question: The party was great ……………………..
questions.description: Fun usually goes after is.

questions.question: Only after her death …………………….. able to appreciate what she did for me.
questions.description: Inversion is used when a sentence starts with only or hardly or seldom.

questions.question: Hardly …………………… I sat down to rest when the doorbell rang.
questions.description: It should be hardly did I sit down or hardly had I sat down.

questions.question: ‘I don’t like oysters.’ ‘……………….. do I.’
questions.description: After a negative remark, we can add another negative remark with 'neither + auxiliary + noun/pronoun.'

questions.question: ……………………….. we heard the gunshots, we rushed upstairs.
Where ……………………. all this while?
questions.description: The present perfect indicates time up to now.

questions.question: It was the last message I ……………………….. from him.
You must be ashamed …………………………
questions.description: Ashamed is used with of. Also when both the subject and the object refer to the same person, we use the reflexive pronoun.

questions.question: When I was at university, I ……………………….. play tennis every evening.
questions.description: We use used to to talk about past habits.

questions.question: She was so frightened ……………………….. she could not even move.
questions.description: The conjunction so...that... expresses cause and effect.

questions.question: …………………….. had she finished one project before she started working on the next.
………………… he was suffering from some health problems, the doctor advised him to take a break.
questions.description: As gives the reason for something.

questions.question: This is the watch ………………………. he bought for me.
questions.description: Either that or which can refer to things in identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: He asked me …………………….. I had seen his purse.
questions.description: Either if or whether can be used to introduce an yes/no question.

questions.question: Hindi as well as Marathi …………………….. spoken in Mumbai.
questions.description: When we connect two singular subjects with as well as, the verb is singular.

questions.question: I have been living in Kerala …………………………. 5 years.
questions.description: Use for to indicate duration.

questions.question: I didn’t go ………………………… I hadn’t been invited.
questions.description: Because gives the reason.

questions.question: ……………………. fast, the cops caught the thief.
If you had invited her, she ....................................
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: …………………………….. on tip-toe, he reached for the apple.
questions.description: The present participle can be used to connect two clauses that depict two actions occurring in quick succession.

questions.question: He will ………………………….. spend the money nor invest it.
questions.description: The conjunction used is neither....nor....

questions.question: This is the hotel ……………………………. our meetings take place.
questions.description: Where can mean in which.

questions.question: I prefer watching television …………………………… reading books.
questions.description: Prefer is followed by the preposition to.

questions.question: ………………………….. I was looking for a book, I came across this old diary.
The hall is …………………………… to accommodate all guests.
questions.description: Enough is goes after the adjective or adverb modified by it.

questions.question: You should ……………………… go to his house, ………………………. talk to him.
…………………………….. did the plane land than there was a loud explosion.
questions.description: Use a comparative expression before than.

questions.question: The germ is too small ………………………………… with the naked eye.
………………………… I had no ticket, I was able to get in.
questions.description: Although is used to connect two contrasting ideas.

questions.question: They live ………………………. the climate is good.
She is ……………………. intelligent to be fooled.
questions.description: Note the pattern too..to...

questions.question: We had an invite …………………………. could not gain admittance anyhow.
questions.description: Use but to connect two contrasting ideas.

questions.question: As he ………………………. older, he started forgetting things.
I ……………………….. anything I have ever done.
I was made ………………………………. .
questions.description: When make is used in the passive form, it is followed by an infinitive with to.

questions.question: Climbing mountains ……………………………. good for health.
questions.description: Here the subject is the ing form climbing. Ing forms are treated as singular.

questions.question: Sam as well his friends ……………………….. at the party.
questions.description: When we connect a singular and plural noun with as well as, the verb agrees with the former.

questions.question: Sam along with his life and children ………………………… in that apartment.
Do you know who ………………………….?
questions.description: In indirect questions, the subject goes before the auxiliary verb.

questions.question: Hardly …………………………. out when it started raining again.
I am anxious ………………………….. his safety.
Each guest ………………………. arrived.
questions.description: Use a singular verb with each and every.

questions.question: Every student …………………….. to hand in their work before Friday.
questions.description: Use a singular verb after every.

questions.question: I ..................... her since the day before yesterday
questions.description: The present perfect is more common with the time expressions for and since.

questions.question: Professionals ..................... nurses and teachers are often underpaid.
questions.description: Either such as or like is possible here. Such as is more formal.

questions.question: The girl ....................... sits next to Sam is his niece.
questions.description: Use who to refer to people use which to refer to things.

questions.question: You …………………………….. do something to improve the situation.
questions.description: Either should or ought to is possible here.

questions.question: You ......................... permit this.
questions.description: Must is a modal auxiliary. Questions and negatives are made without do.

questions.question: I opened the door but …………………... was there.
questions.description: Not anybody means the same as nobody.

questions.question: This is the sixth time you …………………………….. the same question.
questions.description: The present perfect is common after this is the first/second/last etc.

questions.question: He was a ……………………………. child who rarely spoke to anyone.
She is the ……………………………. girl in the class.
questions.description: Chirpiest is the superlative form of chirpy.

questions.question: I failed the test …………………………….. I hadn’t prepared well.
questions.description: Because is a conjunction because of is a preposition.

questions.question: I worked ………………………. the best of my ability.
He assaulted his brother …………………………… he was jealous of him.
questions.description: Because is a conjunction.

questions.question: ‘I didn’t pass the test.’ ‘…………………………. did I.’
questions.description: After a negative statement, we can add another negative statement to it with neither or nor.

questions.question: She is …………………………. beautiful.
questions.description: Too shows unwanted extremes.

questions.question: I am …………………………… happy.
questions.description: We do not use so much to modify adjectives and adverbs.

questions.question: Start at once, …………………………… you do not miss the train.
questions.description: Either so that or in order that cannot be used here.

questions.question: I waited for ………………………… two hours but he didn’t come.
questions.description: We can use another with plural expressions of quantity.

questions.question: Buses leave ………………………….. ten minutes.
questions.description: Every can be used before plural expressions in measurements of frequency.

questions.question: My ……………………………… been stolen.
questions.description: Baggage does not have a plural form.

questions.question: Alice and James ……………………………. agreed to come.
questions.description: When two singular nouns are connected by and, the verb should be plural.

questions.question: He sings as well as ………………………… the guitar.
questions.description: He sings as well as playing the guitar means 'He not only plays the guitar, but also sings.'

questions.question: The more he earns, the …………………………. he spends.
questions.description: Less is the comparative form of little. The comparative is used in both clauses in this structure.

questions.question: It is cruel …………………………… animals in that way.
I was …………………………. tired that I couldn’t walk any further.
questions.description: Note the pattern so...that...

questions.question: If I hadn’t dropped out of college I …………………… a better job.
questions.description: In the third conditional we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would/could/might have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: He took ……………………. his coat.
questions.description: To take off a coat is to remove it.

questions.question: You can do with me what you ……………………
I know you ……………………. lying.
questions.description: Either could be used here. When the main verb is the present tense, the subordinate verb can be in any tense depending upon the context.

questions.question: ……………………. we tried, we could not find a solution to the problem.
questions.description: Fronted adjectives/adverbs are possible in a structure with as or though.

questions.question: The lecture was ………………………..
questions.description: The present participle denotes the people or things that make us feel in a certain way. The past participle denotes how the people or things are feeling.

questions.question: Never ………………………. seen such a mess.
questions.description: Inversion is used when a sentence starts with only or hardly or seldom.

questions.question: Hardly …………………… we arrived when the trouble started.
questions.description: Had is used before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: ‘I have quit smoking.’ ‘……………….. have I.’
As soon as she received the message, she …………………….. for home.
They ……………………….. many objections.
questions.description: Raise is transitive. Rise is intransitive.

questions.question: If I knew the answer, I ……………………. you.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: ‘I can’t swim.’ ‘……………………. can I.’
questions.description: After a negative statement, we can add another negative statement to it with neither or nor.

questions.question: She is ……………………. a kind hearted woman.
questions.description: Use such before an adjective + noun.

questions.question: He worked really hard so that he …………………… the first rank.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, might, would and could are common after so that.

questions.question: She owns …………………….. house in town.
Where are …………………… kids?
I visit my grandparents ………………….. few weeks.
questions.description: Every can be used before plural expressions in measurements of frequency.

questions.question: Have you got a lot of ………………………….?
questions.description: Luggage does not have a plural form.

questions.question: Sania and Rohan ………………………. to the same school.
questions.description: When two singular subjects are connected by and, they take a plural verb.

questions.question: The father as well as his sons ……………………… been arrested for their alleged involvement in the crime.
questions.description: When two subjects are connected by and, the verb agrees with the former.

questions.question: The cat along with her kittens ……………………… in the porch.
questions.description: When two nouns are connected by 'along with', the verb agrees with the former.

questions.question: Between you and ………………………….., I don’t trust him.
questions.description: Between is a preposition. A pronoun used as the object of a preposition should be in its object form.

questions.question: Start at once, so that you ……………………………. late for the meeting.
The council ……………………………. of ten members.
questions.description: Council is a singular subject, so write consists.

questions.question: Later on he ………………………….. his mistake.
He asked ………………………… my name was.
I ……………………….. them for help.
This is the key I was ………………………….
questions.description: To look for something is to search for it.

questions.question: I …………………………. him to go.
questions.description: We use tell before a personal object.

questions.question: He is used to ………………………….
questions.description: Use an ing form after used to.

questions.question: He ………………………. the red shirt.
I would prefer to starve ………………………….. to beg.
He ……………………………. sitting there.
I want to …………………………. for a while.
questions.description: To lie down is to recline.

questions.question: If they informed me earlier, I ………………………… the function.
questions.description: In the second conditional, use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would/could/might + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: Let’s watch a movie, ……………………?
questions.description: Shall we is used in question tags after let's.

questions.question: None of the students participated in the program, ……………………….?
questions.description: Affirmative tags are used after negative expressions like none, hardly, seldom etc.

questions.question: I bought a laptop. Change voice.
questions.description: In the simple past, the passive form is made with was/were + v3.
answers: A laptop is bought by me.
A laptop was bought by me.
A laptop has been bought by me.

questions.question: She was cooking dinner. Change voice.
questions.description: In the past continuous, the passive form is made with was/were + being + v3.
answers: Dinner was being cooked by her.

questions.question: She said to me, ‘I have lost faith in you.’ Change into indirect speech.
answers: She told me she has lost faith in me.
She told me that she lost faith in me.
She told me that she had lost faith in me.

questions.question: If I hadn’t overslept, I …………………….. the train.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if clause and would + have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: Haste ……………………. waste.
The man along with his children ……………………… walking in the rain.
questions.description: When we connect two subject with along with, the verb agrees with the first subject.

questions.question: Thousand dollars ……………………. not a small sum.
I …………………… the office at
A person who works for somebody in order to learn a skill
He decided ………………….. the blue shirt.
There is little water in the pond, …………………….?
questions.description: A non-negative tag is used after negative expressions like little.

questions.question: What does the expression at sixes and sevens mean?
questions.description: To be at sixes and sevens is to be in a state of confusion.

questions.question: The bell …………………….. for over two minutes.
questions.description: To talk about an action or situation that started in the past and has continued up to the present, use the present perfect continuous tense.

questions.question: ……………………. have you been waiting here?
Her children have all …………………….. and left home.
questions.description: The past participle form of grow is grown. The third form of the verb is used after has/have/had.

questions.question: No one came, …………………….?
questions.description: After no one, someone, anyone, we use they in tags.

questions.question: He said, ‘I have an important meeting tomorrow.’ Change into indirect speech.
answers: He said that he has an important meeting the next day.
He said that he had an important meeting the next day.
He said that he has an important meeting tomorrow.

questions.question: If the road hadn’t been slippery, they ………………………. an accident.
questions.description: In the third conditional, use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: Sam, along with his friends, ………………….. on a holiday.
questions.description: Here the subject is the singular noun Sam.

questions.question: Give the opposite of reckless
What does the expression faux pas mean?
You must be back ……………………. 8 o’clock.
If I had completed my studies, I …………………… a better job.
questions.description: In the third conditional we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would/could/might have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: You can eat as much as you ……………………
She said that she ............................ coming.
questions.description: When the main verb is in the past tense, the verb in the subordinate clause too will be in the past tense.

questions.question: ……………………. she tried, she could not solve the problem.
questions.description: Fronted adjectives/adverbs are possible in a structure with as or though.

questions.question: The show was ……………………..
questions.description: The present participle shows the action or people that cause the feeling.

questions.question: He asked me what ................................. doing there.
questions.description: The subject goes before the verb in indirect questions.

questions.question: Hardly ................................ sat down to rest, when someone knocked on the door.
questions.description: Inversion is used when a sentence starts with only or hardly or seldom.

questions.question: Seldom ................................ seen such a mess.
questions.description: Inversion is used when a sentence starts with only or hardly or seldom.

questions.question: 'I don't want to do.' '......................... do I.'
questions.description: After a negative statement we can add another negative statement with neither or nor.

questions.question: I would rather you .............................. now.
questions.description: We use a past tense with a present meaning after would rather.

questions.question: He is intelligent ………………… hard working.
questions.description: Either as well as or and can be used here.

questions.question: ………………….. the girl tried her best, she could not get the first rank.
questions.description: Although is used to connect two clauses.

questions.question: ………………….. he is not educated, he has great practical wisdom.
questions.description: Though is used to connect two contrasting ideas.

questions.question: The doctors treated her well …………………… they could not save her.
questions.description: But is used to connect two contrasting ideas.

questions.question: The mother as well as her children …………………… waiting there.
questions.description: When you connect a singular and a plural verb with as well as, the verb agrees with the first noun.

questions.question: He treated me …………………….. I was a stranger to him.
………………….. it was raining, he opened the umbrella.
questions.description: As gives the reason.

questions.question: ……………………. the servant was honest, his master trusted him.
questions.description: All of these words can indicate the reason.

questions.question: The hall is not …………………… to accommodate all the students.
questions.description: When enough is an adverb modifying an adjective or adverb, it goes after the adjective/adverb modified it.

questions.question: He is ………………….. proud to beg.
He borrowed some money from his friends ……………………. he could buy a car.
questions.description: So that indicates purpose.

questions.question: He offered his daughter a prize, so that she ……………………. work hard.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, the verb in the subordinate clause will also be in the past tense.

questions.question: Don’t they teach any ………………………. at that school?
questions.description: The plural manners means social behaviour.

questions.question: Many are called but ………………………… are chosen.
The old mariner had sailed the seas …………………………. 40 years.
questions.description: We use for with duration.

questions.question: ………………………… are the true makers of history.
questions.description: The masses means the common people.

questions.question: He showed a …………………………… grasp of the problem.
Tie the package with a strong ……………………….
questions.description: A cord is a rope or ropelike something.

questions.question: If you play a few ………………………….. on the guitar, I will sing along.
questions.description: A chord is a string for a musical instrument or a combination of musical tones.

questions.question: With the ……………………….. of all the employees the work was done on time.
questions.description: Cooperation means working together.

questions.question: I don’t believe in …………………………. punishment but I would love to give that boy a spanking.
questions.description: Corporal means bodily or physical. Corporeal has a similar meaning but it is not used in this sense.

questions.question: The coroner was called to examine the …………………………
questions.description: Corpse means dead body.

questions.question: The general’s decision to invade was a …………………………. mistake.
questions.description: Costly is an adjective.

questions.question: Is the witness’s story …………………………?
questions.description: Credible means believable.

questions.question: I ..................... him for the past month.
questions.description: The present perfect is more common with the time expressions for and since.

questions.question: Professionals ..................... doctors and teachers are more useful than artists.
questions.description: We use such as to give examples.

questions.question: The girl ....................... walked in right now is my niece.
questions.description: We use who to refer to people.

questions.question: Something .......................... be done to improve the situation.
questions.description: Ought is followed by an infinitive with to. Ought to is similar to should.

questions.question: You ......................... leave him alone.
questions.description: Must is a modal auxiliary. Questions and negatives are made without do.

questions.question: I opened the door but I didn't see ......................
questions.description: Not anybody means the same as nobody.

questions.question: I rang the doorbell six times but ........................ opened the door.
This is the .......................... movie I have seen.
questions.description: Worst is the superlative form of bad.

questions.question: We got into trouble …………………………. your stupidity.
questions.description: Because of is a preposition. It is used before a noun.

questions.question: He worked ………………………. the best of his ability.
Cain struck Abel …………………………… he was jealous of him.
questions.description: Because is a conjunction. It is used before a clause.

questions.question: A grandparent's job is easier than  ..............................
Are the banks ........................... on Saturdays?
questions.description: We use open as an adjective.

questions.question: Who left the faucets ....................................?
questions.description: We do not open faucets. We turn them on.

questions.question: Can you ..................................... this shoelace?
questions.description: We do not open shoelaces.

questions.question: He ought to be here soon, ....................................?
questions.description: Contracted negative forms of ought are rare in American English.

questions.question: You ought ............................. go.
questions.description: In negative clauses not comes before to.

questions.question: He ran ................................ the room.
questions.description: The opposite of into is out of.

questions.question: I will do it in ................................ way.
questions.description: Myself does not have a possessive form.

questions.question: She lives ..................................
questions.description: When people live on their own, they live without company.

questions.question: I was very ................................... in the discussion.
questions.description: The past participle is used to say how people feel.

questions.question: I didn't enjoy the party because I was ...................................
questions.description: The past participle is used to say how people feel.

questions.question: There is still a glimmer of hope that the strike …………………………….. this week.
questions.description: The simple future is used to make predictions about the future.

questions.question: Parents tend to gloss …………………………….. their children’s mistakes.
questions.description: To gloss over is to excuse or treat lightly.

questions.question: Be a good winner and don’t gloat ……………………………. your victory.
questions.description: To gloat over something is to brag about it.

questions.question: In fairy tales gnomes always …………………………….. hidden treasures.
questions.description: We use the simple present to talk about facts.

questions.question: When something goes wrong, he always makes me the …………………………..
questions.description: To make someone the goat is to make them the fall guy or the victim.

questions.question: The king’s enemies ………………………….. a rebellion.
questions.description: To foment is to provoke.

questions.question: Walking a tightrope ……………………………. the falls was a foolhardy venture.
You should try to forbear ……………………………. saying such nasty things.
questions.description: To forebear from is to refrain from.

questions.question: I forbid you …………………………………. out after midnight.
The bridge had been built with ……………………………… labor.
questions.description: Forced labor means enforced labor.

questions.question: His speech was brief but …………………………..
questions.description: Forceful means powerful or strong.

questions.question: The ………………………………… seizure of US sailors by British naval officers was one of the causes of the war of
questions.description: Forcible means brought about by force.

questions.question: There ………………………….. a famine in Bengal in
questions.description: We use the simple past to talk about finished actions and situations.

questions.question: Gandhi …………………………… in the principle of non-violence.
They have not …………………………. yet.
questions.description: We use a past participle form after has, have and had.

questions.question: She ………………………… not want to quit her job.
questions.description: We make questions and negatives in the simple present tense with do and does. We use does with singular nouns and pronouns.

questions.question: The ozone layer ……………………………… us from harmful ultraviolet radiations.
questions.description: We use the simple present to talk about facts.

questions.question: She ……………………………… her studies before she went abroad.
questions.description: We use the past perfect for the earlier of two past actions.

questions.question: I …………………………….. him on several occasions before he went to America.
questions.description: We use the past perfect for the earlier of two past actions or situations.

questions.question: Jenny …………………………….. alone in her apartment.
questions.description: We use the simple present to talk about facts.

questions.question: When I was young, I …………………………… every day.
questions.description: We use the simple past to talk about past habits.

questions.question: We ……………………………. for Malaysia tonight.
questions.description: We use the present continuous to talk about pre-planned future events.

questions.question: Barking dogs seldom …………………………….
Did you ………………………………. him yesterday?
questions.description: We use the first form of the verb after do, does and did.

questions.question: Please …………………… me here.
questions.description: We use wait for before a direct object.

questions.question: We will have to ………………………
questions.description: We cannot use a that-clause after wait.
answers: wait for the guests to arrive

questions.question: I …………………………. a very long time for his answer.
questions.description: The time preposition for can be dropped after wait.

questions.question: I will write ………………………. when I get home.
questions.description: When write has no direct object, we put to before the indirect object.

questions.question: Write ………………………. a letter when you have time.
questions.description: When there is a direct object, we do not use to before the indirect object.

questions.question: Would you ………………………… some soup?
questions.description: Want is not used in polite expressions of wishes or polite offers.

questions.question: She put ………………………. an interesting suggestion.
questions.description: In expressions like these, forward is always used without –s.

questions.question: If we keep going …………………………… we will get to the top.
questions.description: Upward and upwards are both correct as adverbs.

questions.question: Although I tried all possible ……………………….. communication, I couldn’t get in touch with him.
questions.description: We do not use ways of before a noun.

questions.question: I told him ……………………….. be careful.
questions.description: To give advice, we use object + infinitive.

questions.question: He pretended he ………………………. Swim.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, we use a past tense in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: She said that she …………………………. German.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, we use a past tense in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: That boy does nothing but ……………………… TV.
questions.description: The verb after but usually depends on what came before.

questions.question: I can’t help but …………………. what he is going to do now.
questions.description: Can’t help but is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: She ……………………… believe her eyes.
questions.description: Could hardly is similar to couldn’t.

questions.question: She could get a better job if she …………………….. English.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past in the if-clause and would / could + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: Tennis ……………………… by two or more players.
questions.description: We can use can with a passive infinitive. Be able to is not used in passive structures.

questions.question: It could rain ……………………. this evening.
questions.description: Later is the opposite of earlier.

questions.question: He could have won the race if he ………………………
questions.description: In the third conditional we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would / could have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: I …………………….. someone coming.
questions.description: We do not normally use see in its continuous form when it refers to perception.

questions.question: Janet is the ………………….. of the four sisters.
questions.description: We use the superlative to compare a person or thing with the whole group he/she or it belongs to.

questions.question: I am the happiest mother ……………………… the world.
questions.description: After superlative adjectives we do not normally use of with a singular noun referring to a place.

questions.question: This is …………………… dictionary I could find.
questions.description: The article 'the' is used before superlative adjectives.

questions.question: You don't know him better than ................................. do.
questions.description: Subject pronouns are used before a verb.

questions.question: The dog ……………. the horse.
questions.description: Bit is the past tense of bite.

questions.question: ………………… cats like cold water.
questions.description: Few is similar to hardly any. A few is somewhat similar to some or several.

questions.question: He died in the village ……………………. he was born.
questions.description: Where can mean in which.

questions.question: The dog that ………………… does not bark.
questions.description: The verb in the relative clause should agree with the antecedent of the relative pronoun in number and person.

questions.question: It is nothing else ………………….. pride.
questions.description: Else should be followed by but.

questions.question: She is …………………. intelligent.
questions.description: We do not normally use ‘so’ to indicate a higher degree of something. Very is used with that meaning.

questions.question: He went only ……………… far.
questions.description: That cannot be used as an adverb.

questions.question: He was ………………… tired that he could barely stand.
questions.description: That cannot be used as an adverb. Too cannot be used before a that-clause.

questions.question: He is ………………… exhausted to work.
questions.description: Too means more than enough.

questions.question: The flowers smell ………………….....
questions.description: Smell is a copular verb. We use adjectives to modify copular verbs.

questions.question: It was ………………………… cold.
questions.description: Bitter is an adjective. We cannot use an adjective to modify another adjective. We need an adverb. Bitterly is an adverb.

questions.question: I have never seen a more ……………………….. football match.
questions.description: The past participle is used to say how people feel. The present participle is used to describe the people or things that cause the feelings.

questions.question: His ideas are little different ……………………….. those of his father.
questions.description: We generally use from after different.

questions.question: The new job isn’t ……………………….. different from the old one.
questions.description: Different can be modified by little, any or not much. Many is not possible.

questions.question: This fragrance is ………………………….. different from that.
questions.description: Different can be modified by little. It cannot be modified by few.

questions.question: He is ……………………………. older than his wife.
questions.description: We cannot use very to modify comparatives.

questions.question: ‘Do you know Orwell’s books?’ ‘I haven’t read ……………………….’
questions.description: In negative sentences we use any.

questions.question: Economists doubt ……………………… prices will fall.
questions.description: We can use whether, if or that to introduce clauses after doubt.

questions.question: She was dressed ……………………….. a purple gown.
questions.description: The preposition in is used in this expression.

questions.question: …………………………. her illness, she could not attend the conference.
questions.description: Due to and owing to can both mean because of.

questions.question: She was in Mumbai ………………………… three weeks.
questions.description: We use for to indicate duration.

questions.question: The shop was closed ……………………….. the whole of May.
questions.description: We use during to talk about the whole of a period.

questions.question: Come up and see me ....................................
questions.description: We use sometime or one day to refer to an indefinite time in the future.

questions.question: One of my friends ........................................ a scientist.
questions.description: After one of, the verb is singular.

questions.question: I earn ………………………. money than my wife.
questions.description: We use less with uncountable nouns and fewer with countable nouns.

questions.question: I have got ………………………… problems than I used to have.
questions.description: We use fewer with plural nouns.

questions.question: Choose the ………………………… of the two evils.
questions.description: Lesser can mean smaller in a rather formal style.

questions.question: The government must take immediate action, lest the problem ……………………….. worse.
questions.description: Lest can be followed by should + infinitive or a subjunctive verb.

questions.question: Let’s take a short break, ………………………?
questions.description: Shall we is used as a question tag after let’s.

questions.question: ‘Let’s go for a walk, shall we?’ Yes, ………………………’
questions.description: Let’s is used in short answers.

questions.question: I don’t let the children …………………………. up late.
questions.description: Let is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: He worked ………………………….. a driver for five years.
questions.description: As is used to say what function or role a person or thing has.

questions.question: ……………………….. people can learn a foreign language perfectly.
questions.description: Only a few means the same as few. It is more common in an informal style.

questions.question: Cactuses need ……………………….. water.
questions.description: Only a little means the same as little.

questions.question: The play was …………………………. interesting.
questions.description: We cannot use little to modify other adjectives and adverbs.

questions.question: I waited ……………………………… but he didn’t come.
questions.description: We do not normally use long in affirmative clauses.

questions.question: Break ………………………….. a piece of licorice for me.
questions.description: To break off is to tear off.

questions.question: The mainmast broke ………………………. in the storm.
questions.description: Break away means detach or separate.

questions.question: The trade unions broke ………………………….. negotiations and called a strike.
questions.description: Break off can mean end

questions.question: The convict broke ……………………….. jail.
Give me a complete ………………………… of all the supplies you need.
questions.description: Breakdown can mean categorization or itemized list. Break down is a verb.

questions.question: The argument between the friends led to their ……………………..
questions.description: Breakup is a noun. It means separation or split.

questions.question: The train had a ………………………. outside of Seattle.
questions.description: Breakdown can mean failure or collapse. Break down is a verb.

questions.question: It is so cold you can see your ……………………
questions.description: Breath is a noun. It is the air from your lungs.

questions.question: You only have to ……………………….. that clear mountain air to feel rejuvenated.
questions.description: Breathe is a verb. To breathe is to inhale and exhale.

questions.question: I ……………………….. my hand while making soup.
questions.description: Burned and burnt are both correct as the past tense and past participle of burn.

questions.question: No one will eat that ……………………. cake.
questions.description: Only burnt can be used as an adjective.

questions.question: The burning building gave ...................................... an eerie light.
questions.description: Give off can mean emit.

questions.question: She appears to be very ...................... today.
questions.description: Appear is a copular verb. It is modified by an adjective.

questions.question: She doesn’t want to complete her studies. It .......................... a pity.
questions.description: We do not use appear to talk about subjective feelings and impressions.

questions.question: She suddenly ............................. in the hall.
questions.description: Appear can mean come into sight. Seem is not used with this meaning.

questions.question: I am afraid a problem has ..............................
questions.description: Arise can mean begin or appear.

questions.question: Prices keep ..........................
questions.description: Rise means get higher.

questions.question: I don’t enjoy doing odd jobs ................................ the house.
questions.description: Around and about can both be used to talk about movements that are not very clear or definite.

questions.question: .............................. usually start talking at around 18 months old.
questions.description: No article is used here because we are talking about children in general.

questions.question: I always feed ........................... before I go to work.
questions.description: We use the article ‘the’ here because we are talking about particular dogs.

questions.question: Do you like ..........................?
questions.description: No article is used here because we are talking about dogs in general.

questions.question: He has made .................................
questions.description: Progress is an uncountable noun. We cannot use an article with it.

questions.question: Can I have ............................... pancake?
questions.description: The article ‘the’ is used with next.

questions.question: We have been waiting for rain ................................ weeks.
questions.description: We use for to indicate duration.

questions.question: When the storm subsided, we ....................................... the next village.
questions.description: There is no need to use continued on to, because here the preposition 'on' repeats the same idea as 'continued'.

questions.question: I managed to do ................................ in the test despite not feeling ................................
questions.description: Well is an adverb good is an adjective. Adjectives can only modify nouns adverbs can modify verbs, adjectives and other adverbs.

questions.question: Neither Jane nor ................................. have been to the opera.
questions.description: After neither and nor, we use subject pronouns (he, I, she, they etc.), not object pronouns (him, me, her, them).

questions.question: He thinks that ................................... two can win the doubles match.
questions.description: A pronoun that acts as the subject of a clause should be in the subject form.

questions.question: .................................... vividly, the lighting struck the tall building.
questions.description: The lightning flashed vividly. It struck the tall building. We can combine these two sentences using the present participle 'flashing'.

questions.question: ........................................ by rain we took shelter under a tree.
questions.description: We were driven by the rain. We took shelter under a tree. We can combine these two sentences using the past participle 'driven'.

questions.question: She was given the best treatment. ................................... she died soon after.
questions.description: Despite this can act as a transitional adverb. It is used to present an idea that seems surprising in the light of the previous idea.

questions.question: Will you ...................................... the good tennis balls from the worn ones?
questions.description: Separate is enough to express this idea.

questions.question: Do you like ....................................... of meat pie?
questions.description: The words kind, class, sort, type etc. are all singular and should be used with this or that to modify a singular noun. The words kinds, sorts etc. are used with these and those to modify a plural noun

questions.question: The garden ........................................... used to clip the hedge.
questions.description: Nouns like tongs, shears, tweezers, scissors etc. are always plural and should be used with plural verbs, unless of course the singular aspect is indicated by using `a pair of`.

questions.question: A strimmer is a machine ......................................... grass and weeds.
questions.description: We use 'for + ing' to talk about the purpose of things.

questions.question: You .......................................... working hard.
questions.description: When there are two auxiliaries, the adverb typically goes between them.

questions.question: The meeting was held at a .......................................... hall.
questions.description: Meeting indicates presence of a number of people. So, 'spacious' meaning having much space or room is the correct answer. There is nothing in the sentence to indicate that the meeting or place was special. So, option 1 is incorrect.

questions.question: That he is very ............................................ is evident from the number of friends he has.
questions.description:
A social person likes to be around others or enjoys having conversations with others. Social can also describe things that have to do with society in general. 
A sociable person is easy for others to get along with. Thus, having friends would indicate that he is liked by others and he is easy to get along with. So, sociable is the correct answer.

questions.question: The gangster made a ............................................ attack on the hapless villagers.
questions.description: The word 'hapless' which means miserable or unfortunate, rules out options 1 and 2. 'Bold' would have been correct if the villagers had been strong or at par with the 'gangster'. 'Valiant' is a positive word and does not fit with 'gangster'. Thus, option 3 is the correct answer.

questions.question: He is contesting from the ......................................... constituency of Pune.
questions.description: Urban means something that relates to the city, while urbane describes a level of sophistication and elegance that supposedly would be typical of city folks. So, urban is correct.  Option 3 is incorrect because it is a noun and we need an adjective (suburban) here.

questions.question: Some medicines are not to be taken ...........................................
questions.description: Orally is the correct word here. It means 'by means of or through the mouth'

questions.question: His speeches are so .............................................. that I don`t like to listen to them.
questions.description: The sentence suggests that we need a word to indicate a negative quality in his speeches. Verbose means using or expressed in more words than are needed. It fits here.

questions.question: I don`t trust him so I cannot give you any assurance regarding the ............................................... of his statement.
questions.description: Veracity means conformity to truth or fact, so it makes sense here.

questions.question: The Georgian forces could not ........................................ the Russian advance.
questions.description: Withstand means resist.

questions.question: Sita of the epic Ramayana is known for her ....................................... virtues.
questions.description: 'Womanish' and 'effeminate' are generally used to refer to a man who has or displays qualities considered more suitable for women, whereas womanly is a term of approval and suggests such admirable traits as self-possession, modesty, etc.

questions.question: A ......................................... amount of money has already been wasted on this project.
questions.description: Considerable means rather large or great in size. It fits with 'amount of money' here. So, it is the correct answer. Considerate means careful (of a person) not to inconvenience or harm others.

questions.question: It will not be ......................................... on your part to reject this proposal.
questions.description: Judicious means having, exercising, or characterized by good or discriminating judgment. So, it makes sense here.

questions.question: An ............................................ man is always known for making clever plans.
questions.description: Ingenious means cleverly inventive or resourceful.

questions.question: One day scientists will ......................... find a cure for cancer.
questions.description: 'Be able to' and 'can' can both be used to talk about ability. After will 'can' cannot be used. Only be able to is possible.

questions.question: You are interested in the offer, .........................?
questions.description: We use a negative tag after an affirmative statement. The auxiliary used in the statement is repeated in the question tag.

questions.question: I had never before met ......................... .
questions.description: The correct structure is 'so + adjective + a/an + noun'.

questions.question: I don’t know why they decided to split. They were ......................... in love with each other.
questions.description: Mad is an adjective. Madly is an adverb. We use adverbs to modify verbs.

questions.question: She was ......................... injured in the crash.
questions.description: Deadly is an adjective. It goes before a noun. Fatal is also an adjective. Fatally is an adverb.

questions.question: You can speak .......................... I won’t tell anyone what you say.
questions.description: Free means without payment. Freely means without restriction.

questions.question: I very much enjoy ........................ .
questions.description: The verb enjoy can be followed by a noun/pronoun/-ing form. It cannot be followed by an infinitive.

questions.question: She would never ......................... if she hadn’t changed jobs.
questions.description: The sentence is in the type three conditional. Here we use a past perfect in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the result clause.

questions.question: I don’t trust politicians. I never have, and I ......................... .
questions.description: Parallel structures are used here.

questions.question: I am going to do my exams, and ......................... I am going to study medicine.
questions.description: After cannot be used alone as an adverb. Instead, we use the expression afterwards.

questions.question: I expected to fail the exam, but I passed ......................... .
questions.description: After all can mean contrary to what was expected.

questions.question: When I was ......................... I was working.
questions.description: The structure is/am/are etc. + … age is used without a preposition

questions.question: The cat is inferior …………….. the dog in intelligence.
questions.description: Inferior is followed by to instead of than.

questions.question: When the journalists protested, the minister made no ………………. comments.
questions.description: Further means additional.

questions.question: Chennai is ………………. from Mumbai than Bangalore.
Rahim is senior …………….. all other teachers in the school.
questions.description: Senior is followed by to instead of than.

questions.question: Will you give me ………………. rice, please?
questions.description: We use some in affirmative sentences and any in negative sentences.

questions.question: ………………. knowledge is a dangerous thing.
questions.description: A little means some.

questions.question: ……………… rice we have is enough to feed 10 persons.
questions.description: The little means not much, but all that is there.

questions.question: ……………… knowledge of mathematics that he possessed proved very useful.
questions.description: The little means not much, but all that is there.

questions.question: My cousin ………………… two daughters.
questions.description: When have is used to talk about possessions or relationships, it is not used in the continuous form.

questions.question: Here ……………… our leader!
questions.description: Even though an action is in progress at the time of speaking, present continuous tense is not used if it is an exclamatory sentence.

questions.question: Everything ..................... she said is true.
questions.description: That is common after expressions like all, everything, anything, nothing, few etc.

questions.question: Everybody was there ............................ James.
questions.description: Except and except for are possible after words like all, every, no, anybody etc.

questions.question: ............................... your help, I would have failed.
questions.description: Without and but for are possible here.

questions.question: She has been like that ...................... her childhood.
questions.description: We prefer since here however, from is also possible.

questions.question: ............................... what you think.
questions.description: No matter is a conjunction. It doesn't matter is an expression used to introduce a sentence.

questions.question: This is fourth cake you ................................ this morning.
questions.description: We use a present perfect tense with 'this is the first / second / third / last etc.'

questions.question: Don’t come today. I would rather you .............................. tomorrow.
questions.description: After would rather, we use a past tense to refer to present or future,

questions.question: If I had gone to university, I .............................. business administration.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: Nine o’clock. It is time you ....................... home.
questions.description: After it's time, we use a past tense with present meaning.

questions.question: They ........................... the man from head to foot.
questions.description: To search for is to look for something.

questions.question: I wasn’t pleased ................................ my exam results.
I would rather ............................ it.
questions.description: After would rather, we use an infinitive without to.

questions.question: Would you mind if I .................................. the window?
questions.description: Past tenses are used after 'would you mind?'

questions.question: What does the sentence 'Would you mind opening the window?' mean?
Do you mind people .......................... in the kitchen?
questions.description: After 'do you mind...' we can use an ing form or a clause.

questions.question: Do you mind if people ............................ in the kitchen?
questions.description: We use a present tense in the if-clause after 'do you mind?'

questions.question: I wouldn't mind .......................... this again.
questions.description: Ing forms are used after 'wouldn't mind...'

questions.question: I really ........................... when I went to Singapore.
questions.description: To talk about having a good time, we use the expression 'enjoy myself / ourselves'.

questions.question: I don't enjoy ......................... dinner.
questions.description: Enjoy can be followed by an -ing form.

questions.question: I have seen that film ................................
questions.description: We use many before plural nouns and much before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I ................................ English for three years.
questions.description: We use a perfect tense to say how long a present action or situation has been going on.

questions.question: I am worried about .............................. he is safe.
questions.description: We cannot use 'if' after a preposition. We use 'whether' instead.

questions.question: She insisted on ............................. at once.
questions.description: After prepositions, we normally use -ing forms instead of infinitives.

questions.question: The mother was …………….. inside the house when the children started screaming.
questions.description: Both hardly and scarcely are possible here.

questions.question: It is the same everywhere ……………….. in India.
questions.description: We cannot use except for before prepositions and conjunctions.

questions.question: I don’t like their company. They talk ……………… rubbish.
questions.description: We cannot use the article ‘a/an’ before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I have got too much nose and not ………………
questions.description: Chin is a noun. When enough modifies a noun, it goes before that noun.

questions.question: Come in quietly ………………… she doesn’t hear you.
questions.description: That can be left out in an informal style in some common two-word conjunctions, such as so that, such…that, now that etc.

questions.question: …………….. is a lot of noise in the street.
questions.description: In sentences which say that something exists somewhere we usually use 'there' as a kind of preparatory subject.

questions.question: ……………. he was foreign made it difficult for him to get a job.
questions.description: It is unusual for that-clauses to stand alone as subjects. They are more often introduced by the expression ‘the fact’.

questions.question: Have you got anything ...................... belongs to me?
She wondered why he ………………. there.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, we are more likely to use a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: I was very .....................… in the lesson.
questions.description: We make the past continuous tense forms by putting 'was / were' before the -ing form of the verb.

questions.question: We ………………… by the immigration officer.
She ………………….. in prison for life.
questions.description: When the subject is not the doer of the action we use passive verb forms. In the simple past tense, passive forms are made by putting was/were before the verb.

questions.question: This is the house where I was ……………..
questions.description: Where means ‘in which’. Therefore, we don’t have to use the preposition ‘in’ at the end.

questions.question: Do you know a shop ……………… I can find watches?
questions.description: Where can mean ‘at which’.

questions.question: Do you know the reason …………….. she is angry with me?
questions.description: Both why and for which are possible here.

questions.question: I will never forget the day ……………. I met Sally.
questions.description: When can mean ‘on which’.

questions.question: Here is an article ……………….. might interest you.
questions.description: A relative pronoun acts as the subject or object of the verb in the relative clause. It is therefore wrong to use another subject in the clause.

questions.question: This is the man ……………. my dog bit.
questions.description: Both who and whom are possible here. Whom is used in a formal style.

questions.question: This is the sixth time you ………………… that question.
questions.description: We use the present perfect tense in sentences constructed with 'this is the first / second / last / best etc'.

questions.question: I don’t think …………….. she is coming.
questions.description: Here the clause ‘that she is coming’ is the object of the verb think. We use ‘that’ to introduce noun clauses which act as objects.

questions.question: You ……………… tell Martha. She already knows.
questions.description: Needn’t shows that there is no obligation.

questions.question: You …………….. tell Martha. I don’t want her to know.
questions.description: Mustn’t shows prohibition.

questions.question: He wanted to know when .................................
questions.description: In reported questions the subject normally comes before the verb.

questions.question: He suggested ......................... change my toothbrush.
questions.description: Suggest cannot be followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: Does Amar enjoy ..................... models from clay?
While holidaying in London, Mary ………………… a strong Canadian accent.
…………………. he was, he played well.
………………. she was, she could not find her way.
Their front door was open, …………………. nobody was at home.
The bell for dinner has already ………………..
Stella ………………… wait until her birthday.
There were ………………….. children in the class than expected.
We were given ……………….. work today than yesterday.
The train is now …………………. the Victoria Terminus.
She ………………. her disapproval of the show by leaving the auditorium.
Her questions must have provoked him for they ……………….. a bitter retort.
Her silence merely ……………….. the problem.
This book is an ..................... account of the author’s life.
They bought the apartment at an ………………….. price.
Her shameless affair is the ……………….. in the family cupboard.
If we both put our ……………….. on the table it would be easier to come to an agreement.
That noise is driving me up the ………………….
I could not understand the logic behind his plan, but I decided to ……………….. to his superior knowledge.
He needs something to keep himself ………………….
The auditorium was packed but the speaker disappointed the audience with his ……………… speech.
The rich meal was …………………. by a light dessert.
We can trust her. Her ……………… won’t allow her to cheat.
The ship has its full ………………. of sailors.
We should act before opposition to our plan .....................
The traveler asked the passerby if he ………………….. the way to the nearest inn.
The dentist suggested ……………….. my toothpaste.
He was ..................... his rheumatism by a specialist.
The robber threatened to shoot me ………………… I didn’t give him the money.
There is .....................… that she broke it.
answers: no way to deny the fact
no question of denying the fact

questions.question: Positive hydrogen atoms ....................... to negative oxygen atoms.
I don’t care ……………….. your opinion.
I’m sorry, I broke the vase – I ………………… help it.
Who takes ……………….. the sick?
She is a selfish woman, but you still …………………..  her.
I am the happiest man ...................... the world.
The apartment ………………… I live is very small.
I haven’t bought the ticket. I haven’t ………………….
The books ………………… all over the floor.
I always have trouble …………………  faces.
It …………………. since yesterday morning.
The peasant told the traveler that the weather was stormy and the way ……………….. long.
The only inhabitants of the village said that they ..................... anyone cross the hills in deep snow.
He was so tired that he …………………. barely stand.
If you had asked me I ………………… you with pleasure.
I was going to have lunch when they ………………… me.
No one could explain how the prisoner ...................... from the prison.
This fabric is inferior ………………….. that.
Do you like ....................... of meat pie?
The book ....................... on the table.
The garden shears ..................... used to clip the hedges.
Each of the boys ....................... given a prize today.
A strimmer is a machine used ………………….. grass and weeds.
To ………………….., he failed his exam.
The circus ..................... round of applause for the perfectly timed acrobatic stunt.
answers: audience did receive a well deserved

questions.question: You had better ...................... a specialist.
You must not leave books near the open fire. They …………………. easily.
When will the meeting .......................?
Let’s ………………… this weekend. It is snowing.
I have had ..................... for a bit. I am going home.
He is trying to make a machine that would ………………….. people in wheelchairs to get up stairs.
I really ..................... . when I went skiing last month.
I ....................... for hours, and I was getting tired.
He ...................... ill for a week before they took him to a doctor.
The accused …………………. the verdict with fear and anxiety.
A massive outbreak of influenza ..................... in
He ....................... some of the samples presented to him.
I .....................… some photos to be developed.
It must ....................... to you that she was simply lying.
He ....................... much of his time reading.
He should be properly .....................… by the police.
The pyramids …………………… . around 400 AD.
Positive hydrogen atoms ………………….. to negative oxygen atoms.
I …………………… a whole lot of information.
We ………………….. him an invitation.
My shoes …………………
She likes ……………………
Young children …………………
answers: need to be taken care of

questions.question: My ambition is to spend the ………………….. time working.
I earn as much money as ………………..
Carry straight on till you ………………….. a crossroads.
The baby is …………………. than you.
Your sister looks just ………………… you.
It is best cooked in coconut oil, ………………….. the South Indians do.
He likes football, and ……………….
In 1785, he ………………… to study in Greece.
Thank you very much. That is ……………….. of you.
She is …………………. than stupid.
The laboratory is not only equipped with state-of-the-art scientific instruments …………………… . renowned scientists.
……………………… your supporters’ confidence is as effective as this method.
I did not like his comments on my book but I said nothing as I had agreed to keep quiet.
The report candidly admits that the investor confidence ……………………… considerably.
The child kept on crying while it ……………………
As we approached the swamp, …………………….
Hold the rifle firmly against your shoulder, ……………………..
answers: and then you should take careful aim
and then you have to take careful aim

questions.question: They were ………………………… at the thought of getting caught.
The filter ………………… the drinking water.
I couldn’t ................................... because of the loud noise coming from the streets.
It was ..................................... of him to oppose the chief of robbers.
In a situation like this we can’t say with ................................... what is going to happen next.
I was impressed by his .................................. performance.
He always wins because he is very ...................................
The storm rocked the ship .............................
The artist painstakingly worked ................................... his masterpiece.
